module.p: cf. other uses of the particle a.

Examples from Gairm –
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn. [...] Ach dh’ fheumadh am Fear-stiùiridh ùr barrachd air a sin a dhèanamh. Dh’ fheumadh e siubhal a dhèanamh eadar Rubha Robhanais agus Ceann Bharraidh, eadar am Parbh is Maol Chinn-tìre, agus cha deanadh math dha dìochuimhneachadh gu robh obair a’ Chomuinn a’ buntainn ri Coimisean nan Croitearan an Inbhirnis, ri Roinn an Fhoghluim an Dùn-Eideann, agus ri Tigh nan Cumantan an Lunnainn. An duine a theid do gach àite dhiubh sin, agus a bheir barrachd air còmhradh leis dhachaidh, nì e feum do ’n Chomunn is do ’n Ghàidhlig. [...]
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] He would have enough to do initially reforming the Society. [...] But the new leader would have to do more than (just) that. He would have to travel between the Butt of Lewis and Barra Head, between Cape Wrath and the Mull of Kintyre, and he should not forget that the Society’s work is related to the Crofters’ Commission in Inverness, to the Education Department in Edinburgh, and to the House of Commons in London. The person who goes to each of those places, and who brings home more than (just) conversation, will benefit the Society and the Gaelic language. [...] td. 105, ‘Air An Spiris’ conjunction, human
[...] Bha Mairead ’na suidhe ann an cathair ris an teine is plaide timcheall air a glùinean. Bha Màiri a’ deanamh na dìnneir. Dh’ innis e dhaibh gur esan an duine a sgrìobh thuca, a dh’ fhaighneachd am b’ urrainn dha a thighinn. [...]
[...] Margaret was sat in a chair by the fire with a blanket around her knees. Mary was making the dinner. He told them that he was the man who had written to them, asking if he could come. [...] td. 169–70, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
Bha feallsanach mar Hegel a’ togail riaghailtean móra a dheanadh an saoghal air a thaobh a-muigh fhéin soilleir, ach cha b’ ann mar sin a bha Kierkegaard.
A philosopher like Hegel constructed grand rules which made the external world itself clear but K. was not like that. td. 103

Other examples from modern usage –
Bha a h-uile duine a dh’aithnicheadh e a’ smaoineachadh gu robh beatha shòlasach aig Ailig Smart. [...]
Everybody who got to know him thought that Alec Smart had a good life. [...] td. 103

Biblical examples –
A Nis is iad so ainmeanna chloinn Israeil, a thàinig do’n Eiphit; thàinig gach duine agus a theaghlach maille re Iacob: Reuben, Simeon, Lebhi, agus Iudah, Isachar, Sebulun, agus Beniamin, Dan, agus Naphtali, Gad, agus Aser. Agus na h-anman uile a thàinig a mach a leasraidh Iacoib, bu deich agus tri fichead anam iad; oir bha Ioseph ’san Eiphit a cheana. [...]
Now these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob. Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin, Dan, and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher. And all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were seventy souls: for Joseph was in Egypt already. [...] [KJV] Ecsodus I.1–5

Examples from Gairm –
Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. Dh’ fhàg Eóghan Mac-a- phì a sheula fhéin air an an sin, agus air a’ Bh.B.C. an Albainn gu h-iomlan, agus air dha a nis a dhreuchd a leigeil dheth, dh’ iarramaid taing a thoirt dha airson gach seirbhis a thug e do ar cànain, is ghuidheamaid dhà saorsainn is toileachas ’na shaorsa, agus obair ás ùr anns na raointean a thaghas e. [...]
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. Ewan MacPhee has left his own stamp on that Department, and on the BBC in Scotland as a whole, and after him now giving up his job, we would ask for thanks to be given him for all the service he has given to our language, and wish him liberty and pleasure in his freedom, and new work in the areas that he will choose. [...] td. 297, ‘Air An Spiris’ abstract

Biblical examples –
[...] A nis dh’éirich righ ùr air an Eiphit, do nach b’aithne Ioseph. [......] Agus thug Pharaoh àithne d’a shluagh uile, ag ràdh, Gach mac a bheirear tilgidh sibh ’san abhainn, agus gach nighean gleidhidh sibh beo.
[...] Now there arose up a new king over Egypt, which knew not Joseph. [......] And Pharaoh charged all his people, saying, Every son that is born ye shall cast into the river, and every daughter ye shall save alive. [KJV] Ecsodus I.8–22

Examples from Gairm –
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. [...] Dé na rudan a dh’ fhaodadh sinn iarraidh? Tuilleadh de luchd-teagaisg ’s de luchd-ceasnachaidh Gàidhlig. Airgead gu leabhraichean uallachadh is a chlo-bhualadh. Barrachd tìde air an réidio agus air telebhisean. [...] Chan eil an sin ach rud no dhà a dh’ fhaodamaid iarraidh. [...]
[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. [...] What are the things that we could demand? More Gaelic teachers and inspectors. Money to prepare and print books. More time on the radio and on television. [...] Those are just a couple of things that we could demand. [...] td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’

Older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh.
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. td. 5

Examples from Gairm –
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. Tha e iomchuidh aig an àm gun tugamaid tarraing air a’ chuspair so. [...]
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. It is pertinent at the [present] time that we [would] comment upon this subject. [...] td. 105, ‘Air An Spiris’ human, non-restrictive
’S bha iad ’nan suidhe an sin ag òl uisge-beatha fad na h-oidhch’, na ceathrar aca. An dràsda ’s a rithist shealladh Iain a-mach air an uinneig ris a’ mhuir ’s na h-eileanan. [...] Chaidil e airson greiseag ’s nuair a dhùisg e anns a’ mhadainn bha a bheul salach le blas an uisge-bheatha. Choisich e mach ás a’ bhàta a-measg nam faoileagan, ga[n] sguabadh air falbh le a làmhan, agus lean e air suas an aon rathad a bh’ ann gus an ruigeadh e an tigh. [...]
And they were sat there drinking whisky all night, the four of them. Now and again John would look out the window at the sea and the islands. [...] He slept for a bit and when he woke up in the morning his mouth was dirty with the taste of the whisky. He walked out of the boat among the gulls, brushing them away with his hands, and he continued up the only road that there was until he reached the house. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn masculine
Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. [...] Mar a bhios obair a’ Bh.B.C. a’ leudachadh anns a’ Ghaidhealtachd—agus tha fhios gun tachair so leis na stéiseanan ùra a thathas a’ togail—bithidh sùil againn ri daoine ùra ’s ri dòighean ùra. [...] Bhitheadh e iomchuidh gun deigheadh uairean a chur air leth airson luchd-Gàidhlig sna sgoiltean—chan ann a chùm cànan a theagasg dhaibh, ach a chùm eòlas a thoirt dhaibh air eachdraidh, air ceòl, air cruth is air caitheamh-beatha an t-saoghail mhóir, air cuspair sam bith a tha iomchuidh agus feumail do chloinn sgoile—tre Ghàidhlig. A thaobh ciùil, nach bu chòir do ’n Bh.B. C. a bhith ceum air thoiseach air càch, a’ deilbh dhòighean is chruthan ùra, gun dearmad a dhèanamh air na rudan luachmhor a tha nar dìleab? Tha aca ri sùil a chumail air an aois ’s air an òigridh, agus chan eil sinn gun dòchas gun tarraing iad air ais bho shloc nan daolagan pàirt de òigridh na Gàidhlig, agus gu seall iad dhaibh nach do chaill ceòl nan Gaidheal a’ bhuaidh a bha aige air ar sluagh fad cheudan bliadhna. Bithidh cuideachadh a dhìth air luchd a’ Bh.B.C., agus ’se an cuideachadh a b’ fheàrr a b’ urrainn dhuinn a thoirt dhaibh ar n-ùidh a nochdadh, le bhith a’ sgrìobhadh thuca, gam moladh is gan càineadh, ag iarraidh tuilleadh tìde do ’n Ghàidhlig, is a’ sealltainn dhaibh gu bheil sinn a’ dèanamh feum de ’n tìde a th’ againn.
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. [...] As the work of the BBC will be expanding in the Highlands – and it is known that this will happen with the new stations that are being established – we will be expecting new people and new methods. [...] It would be appropriate that times would be set aside for Gaelic speakers in the schools – not to teach them language, but to pass on knowledge to them on history, on music, on the form and the lifestyle of the world at large, on any subject that is suitable and useful to schoolchildren – through Gaelic. On the subject of music, shouldn’t the BBC be a step ahead of the rest, producing new methods and forms, without neglecting the valuable things that are in our inheritance? They have to keep an eye on old age and on the youth, and we are not without hope that they will pull back part of Gaelic-speaking youth from the pit of beetles, and that they will show them that the Gael’s music has not lost the effect that ithas had on our people for hundreds of years. The BBC people will need help, and the best help that we can give them is to show them our interest, by writing to them, praising them and criticising them, demanding more time for Gaelic, and showing them that we are making use of the time that we have. td. 297, ‘Air An Spiris’
[...] “Rinn e òran dhomh. Oran briagha. [...] Cha robh sinn ach fichead bliadhna a dh’ aois. [...] ’Se Sasunnach a bh’ ann [...]. Cha robh e ach fichead bliadhna a dh’ aois. Balach àrd tapaidh le léine shìoda. Thubhairt e rium gum pòsadh e mi.” Thòisich i a’ crònan fonn a bha cumanta bliadhnachan air ais—air feadh an t-samhraidh ud. [...]
[...] “He sang me a song. A beautiful song. [...] We were just twenty years of age. [...] He was an Englishman [...]. He was just twenty years of age. A tall strong boy with a silk shirt. He said to me that he would marry me.” She started to hum a melody that was popular years ago – all through that summer. [...] td. 170, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Other examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. Rinn e sin tro dhìcheall, obair chruaidh agus tàlant malairt a bha neo-ghnàthach. An-diugh tha iomadh companaidh na ainm air feadh na Gàidhealtachd. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. He did that through duty, hard work and a talent for business that was unusual. Today there are many companies in his name all over the Highlands. [...] td. 5

Examples from Gairm –
[...] Choisich e mach ás a’ bhàta a-measg nam faoileagan, ga[n] sguabadh air falbh le a làmhan, agus lean e air suas an aon rathad a bh’ ann gus an ruigeadh e an tigh. Cha robh e duilich tigh Maireid a lorg. “’S iongantach mar a bhios iad a’ smaoineachadh gur ann a reic rudeigin a thainig mi,” thubhairt e ris fhéin le seòrsa de ghàire, ’s e a’ sealltainn ris an inneal a bha e slaodadh. Bha Mairead ’na suidhe ann an cathair ris an teine is plaide timcheall air a glùinean. [...]
[...] He walked out of the boat among the gulls, brushing them away with his hands, and he continued up the only road that there was until he reached the house. It was not difficult to find Margaret’s house. Margaret was sat in a chair by the fire with a blanket around her knees. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. Dh’ fhàg Eóghan Mac-a- phì a sheula fhéin air an an sin, agus air a’ Bh.B.C. an Albainn gu h-iomlan, agus air dha a nis a dhreuchd a leigeil dheth, dh’ iarramaid taing a thoirt dha airson gach seirbhis a thug e do ar cànain [...]. Anns an aon fhacal chuireamaid fàilte air Fread MacAmhlaidh a tha a’ togail an eallaich. Tha sinn eòlach air a ghuth agus air obair, agus ghuidheamaid gach soirbheachadh leis. [...]
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. Ewan MacPhee has left his own stamp on that Department, and on the BBC in Scotland as a whole, and after him now giving up his job, we would ask for thanks to be given him for all the service he has given to our language [...]. In the same word we would welcome Fred MacAulay who is taking up the burden. We know his voice and his work, and we would wish him every success. [...] td. 297, ‘Air An Spiris’ human, proper noun/name, non-restrictive

Examples from Gairm –
Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. [...] Mar a bhios obair a’ Bh.B.C. a’ leudachadh anns a’ Ghaidhealtachd—agus tha fhios gun tachair so leis na stéiseanan ùra a thathas a’ togail—bithidh sùil againn ri daoine ùra ’s ri dòighean ùra. [...]
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. [...] As the work of the BBC will be expanding in the Highlands – and it is known that this will happen with the new stations that are being established – we will be expecting new people and new methods. [...] td. 297, ‘Air An Spiris’ abstract, passive object extraction

Examples from Gairm –
[...] Bha Mairead ’na suidhe ann an cathair ris an teine is plaide timcheall air a glùinean. Bha Màiri a’ deanamh na dìnneir. Dh’ innis e dhaibh gur esan an duine a sgrìobh thuca, a dh’ fhaighneachd am b’ urrainn dha a thighinn. [...] Shuidh e air cathair. “Tha sinn airson feadhainn de na h-òrain as aithne dhuibh a chur air clàr, gus nach teid iad air chall.” [...]
[...] Margaret was sat in a chair by the fire with a blanket around her knees. Mary was making the dinner. He told them that he was the man who had written to them, asking if he could come. [...] He sat [down] on a chair. “We are wanting to put some of the songs that you know on record, so that they are not lost.” [...] td. 169–70, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Other examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. Rinn e sin tro dhìcheall, obair chruaidh agus tàlant malairt a bha neo-ghnàthach. An-diugh tha iomadh companaidh na ainm air feadh na Gàidhealtachd. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. He did that through duty, hard work and a talent for business that was unusual. Today there are many companies in his name all over the Highlands. [...] td. 5

Examples from Gairm –
Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. [......] Bithidh cuideachadh a dhìth air luchd a’ Bh.B.C., agus ’se an cuideachadh a b’ fheàrr a b’ urrainn dhuinn a thoirt dhaibh ar n-ùidh a nochdadh, le bhith a’ sgrìobhadh thuca, gam moladh is gan càineadh, ag iarraidh tuilleadh tìde do ’n Ghàidhlig, is a’ sealltainn dhaibh gu bheil sinn a’ dèanamh feum de ’n tìde a th’ againn.
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. [......] The BBC people will need help, and the best help that we can give them is to show them our interest, by writing to them, praising them and criticising them, demanding more time for Gaelic, and showing them that we are making use of the time that we have. td. 297, ‘Air An Spiris’

Other examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. [...] Bha seachdnar de theaghlach aige, ceathrar mhac agus triùir nighean, agus bha a h-uile fear is tè anns a’ mhalairt ach Rob. B’ e Rob a b’ òige agus lean e an sgoil. Nuair a ràinig e an t-oilthigh bha càch airson gun ionnsaicheadh e cunntasachd, a bhiodh feumail anns a’ mhalairt, ach ’s ann a bha ùidh-san ann an ealain. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. [...] He had a family of seven, four sons and three daughters, and every man and woman was in the business except Rob. Rob was the youngest and he stayed on at school. When he reached the university the others wanted him to learn accountancy, which would be useful in the business, but his interest was in art. [...] td. 5
cf. mar a, nuair a, ged a.
cf. dè a ... ?, cò a ... ?, carson a ... ?, cuin a ... ?.
